title: 107_hr2683
content: The Sales Tax Equity Act of 2001, also known as the "Sales Tax Equity Act," allows for the deduction of state and local general sales taxes instead of state and local income taxes. The Sales Tax Equity Act of 2001 allows taxpayers to deduct state and local general sales taxes instead of state and local income taxes. The Sales Tax Equity Act of 2001 allows taxpayers to deduct state and local general sales taxes imposed at one rate on a broad range of items, including food, clothing, medical supplies, and motor vehicles. The tax does not apply to some items, but this exclusion does not affect the tax's classification as a general sales tax. The Sales Tax Equity Act of 2001 allows deductions for state and local general sales taxes imposed at one rate on various items. Lower tax rates on certain items do not impact the tax classification. No deduction is allowed for sales taxes imposed at rates other than the general rate, except for specific items with lower tax rates. Compensating use taxes are treated as general sales taxes. The Sales Tax Equity Act of 2001 allows deductions for state and local general sales taxes imposed at one rate on various items, including compensating use taxes. Special rules apply for motor vehicles where the general rate is used if the tax rate exceeds it. The Sales Tax Equity Act of 2001 allows deductions for separately stated general sales taxes paid by consumers to the seller. The amount of deduction is determined by tables prescribed by the Secretary. The Sales Tax Equity Act of 2001 allows deductions for general sales taxes paid by consumers based on average consumption by taxpayers on a State-by-State basis. The deductions need only be determined for adjusted gross incomes up to a certain amount. The amendments made by this section shall have an effective date. The amendments made by the Sales Tax Equity Act of 2001 will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act.
